intro: Quercus vreelandii, commonly known as the Vreeland oak, is a rare and endangered species of oak native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its small, acorn-like fruits and broad, lobed leaves that turn vibrant colors in the fall. The tree typically grows in wetland habitats, such as swamps and floodplains, where it thrives in moist, acidic soils. Its slow growth rate and limited distribution make it a unique subject of botanical study. Conservation efforts are crucial to preserving this species due to habitat loss and environmental changes.
